comments.commentBody: Wow. Is this just some run-away rampant victim mentality? You seriously believe what you are writing?

The Rhodes interview is a two-day process: on the Friday night before Thanksgiving, every district holds a reception during which, among other things, applicants are assigned interview times for the next morning. After around 2pm on Saturday, following the last interview, the selectors deliberate and call some of the applicants up for second interviews. Each district has ~12-13 finalists and selects two as Rhodes Scholars, on the spot, on Saturday night, after this second round (and more deliberation).

It's not a process that can be bypassed or individually adjourned and, as the NYT suggests, it's one whose schedule is clearly stated from the outset. While it's not my place to judge whether or not Witt made the 'right' choice, I do think, given the nature of the process, that the "heat" the Rhodes Trust has taken is unjustified.

Moreover, let's not forget about the real tragedy that occurred that day. It's not a). that Yale lost; b). that Witt forewent a shot at a 2012 Rhodes Scholarship; nor c). that Williams (it seems) lied. During the game, a woman died in a tragic tailgating accident in which two others were seriously injured. Not a good day for the Bulldogs.
NRWC
That someone would consider such a choice as worth making should have disqualified him from any candidacy for any scholarship.
Shouldn't that be "fraudian"?

Quite the unfounded and illogical knee jerk biased emotional response. Do you KNOW for a fact Affirmative Action mandates were in play?

Based on your conjecture and "logic", Jerry Sandusky (a White coach) and his child molestation scandal resulted because Affirmative Action was not in play and the criminal actions and scandal would not have occurred if they had just hired a Black coach.
Soho - you're out of place and out of line. This has nothing to do with race, so leave it out, thanks very much.
So unnecessary.
affirmative action at work

Liar, liar, pants on fire.
You're fired.
Like rob a bank?

Two or more players, each with their own Sphero, could probably play a lot of different games on an obstacle course the size of a living room or of a city block.

There real issue with this technology is whether it can easily be modified for bad purposes.
He's not that good-looking!

What a twisted mind you have.  The "Tax cut bill" $40 every two weeks for those who work for wages, plus a "doctor fix" to pay a fair amount to those among us that treat our sickness, and lastly provides a small help to those unemployed to make ends meet until a job can be found.  I am certain that a significant number of those people will donate to others in need...they always have.  If the bill is passed, surely your religious deity will give credit to all those who voted for it as well as those citizens who support their yes vote on it...right?

Mr. Obama has taken the moderate Republican position, the Republicans went off the deep end, and there is no liberal political party anywhere on the horizon of America's future. So it's a pretty dull discussion of worn out shibboleths.

We are a secular nation...it is no more evident to what is going on in Washington...3 days before Christmas. Forget the "time of goodwill." or the meaning of Christmas...the "spirit of giving."

Starting with the president of the United States, Mr. Obama...the twitter campaign to arouse division and doubt among those that are needy, further degrading our government in Washington....to what end...his re-election.

So, through sheer manipulation of issues and cunning tactics, President Obama wins re-election...What then?

It will be 4 more years of gridlock in Washington...ripping the nation apart...creating enclaves of Americans with special interests and goals. The United States, will not be united anymore.

Then, there are those that want to take the country back (possibly the House members that stopped the tax relief bill)...they too have defined the meaning of a secular nation....a strange way of observing the tradition of Christmas.

Is it possible that the politics of governing...overrides the religious stance that some of our politicians claim?
Anything new about the Islanders situation? Fish Sticks ownership seems to be in a deep freeze, as do Nassau County lawmakers.

"Those who wish to restore one will support the abolition of a tax on incomes, against the advice of the late Professor Adam Smith of Glasgow."

I would definitely support the abolition of a tax on incomes or if not that, then start weighting people's votes higher whopay a higher income tax rate.

I don't have a real strong opinion on the gold standard vs paper money because I haven't read a good debate between the pros/cons of each.

If Nate wrote an article on the matter, perhaps I could be more trusting to an objective look on the matter.

@Kate in Boston: You're wrong.  Read 8 USC Section 1325 which makes it a CRIMINAL misdemeanor to enter this country illegally.  And all subsequent violations are felonies.  But I can understand how you came to misunderstand the law as the New York Times, and others in the so-called main stream media have printed your false claim on many, many occasions.

To quote another poster:

"The reporter posted this in response to another comment:

Donations can be sent to:

New York Legal Assistance Group
The Angel Fund
7 Hanover Square
18th floor
New York, N.Y., 10004
Attention: Randye Retkin"

Angel has a good option. He can get the transplant in Mexico for a fraction of the price it would cost in the US. Is there a law preventing his children from joining him in Mexico? Even if his family can't or won't join him permanently in Mexico, would they rather be visiting his grave in the US or visiting him alive in Mexico until a way can be found to bring him back to the US?

Even if he has a transplant operation, who will pay the thousands of dollars per year in anti rejection medications? Does Angel have the money? His employer? His family?

I'm not blaming anyone for this person situation. I'm just saying that you won't solve anything by cutting the financing of medical services for illegal migrants, and that you need to focus your attention in other issues to solve your health care problem. Your health care financing problem is not a consequence of illegal migration.

Some of you are actually blaming migrants for not having access to proper health services, and that's not true. This is the easiest argument for the people who don't want to face the real health care problem: it costs a lot, it demands an enormous amount of money and you don't want to pay for it. You want the service, but you want to reduce taxes and public expenditure, and that's a contradiction. This is the main problem, with or without illegal aliens.

Continue blaming migrants, and you will continue with your problem.

Who is talking about slave labor ? Of course that is wrong, what a simplistic statement to make, Steve B. Did you read my post ?
And @ Ordinary Person: Most Mexicans are not waiters, but mostly dishwashers and cleaning crew. Go work in a restaurant and see for yourself.

"You shall not wrong a stranger or oppress him, for you were strangers in the land of Egypt. You shall not afflict any widow or orphan"

... but what about the people wronged when this person entered the country illegally? Should this edict not also apply to the people who come here and require the resources that widows and orphans would have been able to avail themselves of had it not been taken by them?

Did the people of faith who entered this country under false pretenses act honorably either?

I grow weary of the "poor misunderstood illegal immigrant." People know exactly what they are doing when they decide to cross the border. Anyone interested in looking into what Mexico's laws on illegal immigration are? Ever wonder what they do with the people the catch crossing over from Guatemala?

On a personal, human level I truly feel for this person and do not wish anyone harm or decline of health. As other posters have stated, if I or my family get sick, we are on our own medically and financially. A selective safety net that rewards rule breakers at the expense of law abiders is patently unfair.

It's an unfortunate situation for all and there is no easy answer.
I-see-Sphero-drag-races in bars, dorms, parking lots . . .
Will my dog glow after he eats it?
Note to Air Force: always require a password before allowing bluetooth pairing...

Ellis, as I recall, was suspended for a year without pay. I'd hardly call that a slap on the wrist. Williams, by contrast, resigned, before any punishment -- a slap on the wrist or otherwise -- could be levied, so I honestly can't tell how @Tina is able to draw any meaningful comparison at all. All I see here is a race card.

A few months ago, there was similar enthusiasm for some cube- shaped toys whose name escapes me. I'm expecting on this basis that next month or soon thereafter, a new toy in pyramidal shape will appear in this space.
Did you not receive a Galaxy Nexus review unit?  I'm quite surprised that that wasn't the subject of this week's review.  But I guess it's not a new Apple product.

Hmmmm.  I'm picturing this orb as the snitch in the quidditch games that are still popular on some college campuses.  Yep, I think it could make a dandy snitch.  A flying remote-controlled orb would be even better, but for now this will have to do.

Honestly, I've seen enough race cards dealt in the comments column to open a casino. Lying is lying is lying. What part of that doesn't @Yvette understand? What part of it is acceptable? What part of it has anything -- legitimately -- to do with race?
